captions.text: Er-neener-neener-neener-neener-nee~
Wave hi to the camera!

Good morning, John, it's Wednesday, February
eleventh,

and I'm almost entirely sure that I actually got the
date right this time!
It's Wednesday!
[Singing] Song Wednesday!
This song is a little bit different than usual,
because instead of recording with me and my acoustic guitar,
and then later going to the studio to record it for my album,
I just recorded it at the studio to start with,
so you're getting the studio version,
first-ever viewing,
here, on Brotherhood 2.0!
I'm not really sure what to call this song.

I've got a few ideas, but I was wondering
if you guys had ideas, as well,

so if you could leave those in the comments,
the best one I will choose, and then I'll

link to your channel in the sidebar, which
is actually over there [not anymore].

Without further ado, here's my song about
an anglerfish!
[Upbeat music]
[Song ends]
I hope that you enjoyed that!
Please don't forget to leave potential song

titles in the comments; I need to get a title
of the song!
And, secondarily, DFTBA Records is having the DFTBA Radio Hour tonight,
in which Toddly00 and Caitlin Sky will be talking about
all things nerdy, all things DFTBA, all things musical, and all things awesome.
9:00 PM, Eastern Standard Time!
There's a link in the sidebar.
John, I hope you enjoyed my music!
I enjoyed your Question Tuesday, and I especially enjoyed Captain Willie's Voyage of a Failboat.
Don't forget to be awesome.

comments.author: Devo Davis

comments.text:
I really like this song, and that not because it catchy, or factual, or 
even because it's the second Hank song I heard. It has a message, "hidden 
in plain sight." If you look at lines like "Yeah that deep sea anglerfish 
has no reason to be happy but she has no freaking idea what else to be." 
and "I don't have any friends and I don't have any hair, but neither does 
the anglerfish and she doesn't care." you can kinda see the Hank could also 
be telling us that we don't need to be perfect, just happy :)﻿

comments.text:
+Glen Williams Wow, I don't know where I got that information from. My life 
is a lie. Sorry about the incorrect information, but I thought one of them 
(John or Hank) mentioned either TMBG or Jonathan Coulton. Can't be sure 
which. Ah! I figured it out. I must have read Jonathan Coulton's Pandora 
biography wrong and misinterpreted it to mean that he was a member of TMBG, 
instead of just being *influenced* by them. Sorry, DFTBA.

comments.author: Angela Mammel

comments.text:
This is actually really pretty deep (no pun intended...) There is so much 
that we strive to attain that we only want because we know it's there. If 
it was absolutely impossible for any one person to have more than, say, a 
hundred thousand dollars, we would all be perfectly happy with that amount 
or less. We are always discontent because we know that there is more... But 
really, we can be happy with whatever we allow ourselves to be happy with.﻿

comments.author: onemadhungrynomad

comments.text:
I feel like this is a deeper song than we all think. The angler fish has no 
idea what light looks like and is happy in that bliss. We as children don't 
understand friendship or love and thus don't crave it but once we see the 
light bam there it is and you want it. So the question is is it better to 
never see the light and be happy or to see the light and have to know it 
will fade away. ﻿
comments.author: andrew martin

comments.text:
+andrew martin I think Hank would agree that the question isn't even a 
question, it is better to accept and appreciate the fragility and 
temporariness of Life then to so jadedly deny it's benefits to live in 
comfortable melancholy.
